intro: Bradleia mollis, commonly known as the velvetleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its broad, velvety leaves and showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is known for its hairy stems and lobed foliage. Bradleia mollis thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its unique botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological studies and horticultural interest.
